Award.AwardTitle: Facility Support: The WiscSIMS National Ion Microprobe
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will renew funding of WiscSIMS as a National Facility for Stable Isotope Geochemistry. The lab has been funded by NSF as a National Facility since 2008. WiscSIMS has optimized an IMS-1280 large-radius, multi-collector ion microprobe for analysis of stable isotopes (including Li, C, N, O, Mg, Si, S, Ca, and Fe). WiscSIMS has developed unique capabilities for precise and accurate analysis of isotope ratios from small to ultra small spots. The ability to analyze small spots (1-10 micron) in situ from microscope mounts allows data to be put in context with imaging and other forms of analysis. Over 50% of instrument beam-time has been devoted to earth science and NSF-supported projects. Thus far, over 206 scientists have worked with WiscSIMS from 60 different universities and research institutes.

A wide range of research is conducted at WiscSIMS. The three most common areas are Igneous and Metamorphic Petrology & Geochemistry; Cosmochemistry & Astrobiology; and Low Temperature Geochemistry & Paleoclimatology. The applications of these new in situ capabilities are potentially transformative in many areas of geochemistry. During the next three-year funding cycle, research to be conducted at WiscSIMS will help resolve long-standing paleoclimate questions, especially in proxy records of rapid climate change where conventional techniques cannot resolve short time periods. The broader impacts of this project include new applications of stable isotope geochemistry to problems of societal concern; public education; and SIMS/geochemistry training at undergraduate to post-doc level, including under-represented groups. Forty-five students, including 20 women, used WiscSIMS in thesis research during the past 3 years. WiscSIMS hosted the Hi-Res Paleoclimate Workshop in 2013 and proposes to host Hi-Res2015.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This grant has provided novel analytical capabilities resulting in 67 papers, 170 abstracts and 20 theses. These publications demonstrate the role of WiscSIMS as a center of excellence in stable isotope geochemistry, and the breadth of projects that have been completed. New hardware, standards, and protocols have been developed for in situ microanalysis of stable isotope ratios. Over 300 scientists have used the WiscSIMS Facility. For the period 2014-17, the 129 researchers include 34 external PI’s who had NSF funding for their projects, 48 who were students at the time they worked at WiscSIMS, and advisers or collaborators who published data from WiscSIMS. These studies have answered fundamental questions relating to Earth Science, Engineering, Chemistry, Biology and Physics. Societal concerns have been emphasized such as paleoclimate, mineral and energy resources, and the environment.

 

Many significant studies resulted from this grant, including:

  1. The oldest reliably dated piece of the Earth, a 4.4 Ga zircon, has been analyzed for Pb and oxygen isotope ratios, and water content. These results show that the geochemistry of the zircon is preserved from its parent igneous rock and support the existence of oceans and conditions habitable to life as early as 4.3 billion years ago, over 800 million years before the oldest confirmed microfossils.
  2. The strength of summer monsoon has been estimated from microanalysis of oxygen isotope ratios in a speleothem from Kulishu cave, China that shows differences in sub-annual seasonality after the last Glacial Maximum.
  3. Putative microfossils from the 3.46 Ga Apex chert were analyzed for carbon isotope ratio. These are the oldest microfossils with correlated morphology and geochemistry, confirming the existence of microbial consortia and suggesting that life emerged on Earth before 3.5 Ga.
  4. Lower Paleozoic sandstones of the Illinois Basin contain carbonate cements that are zoned in oxygen and carbon isotope ratios.  Systematic variability up to 10‰/ 100 microns demonstrates a long period of cementation during burial punctuated by infiltration events of external fluids and clay diagenesis. This variability in single cements nearly equals the variability reported in carbonate cements through the Illinois Basin.
  5. Quartz overgrowths in the Cambrian Mt. Simon sandstone from the Wisconsin Arch and Illinois Basin show systematically declining values of d18O varying by over 10‰ in less than 100 mm due to burial, heating and pressure solution. In contrast, Si isotopes in most cements are homogeneous with the prominent exception of late quartz overgrowths from just above the Precambrian unconformity in Wisconsin that vary by up to 6‰ in d30Si due to remobilization of low-d30Si silcretes. Individual overgrowths show variability in d30Si that is more than 50% of the total variability on Earth.
  6. The WiscSIMS IMS-1280 has been modified to allow accurate analysis of oxygen 3-isotopes in spots as small as 1-micron.  This new capability permits analysis of comet particles that are less than 10-microns in diameter. The results demonstrate mixing of inner and outer domains of the Solar Nebula during the formation of planets.
